content.title: Muoki, gastronomy's latest generation

introduction.small: In Gangnam, one of Seoul's most famous districts, Muoki reinvents food into a truly unusual gourmet experience.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Muoki, gastronomy's latest generation

paragraphs.text:
As soon as it opened, Muoki has established itself as a pioneer of creative gastronomy in Seoul. The restaurant pays tribute to South Africa, from the decoration to the plate. Muoki means “oak” in Afrikaans, just like the tree under which chef James Park used to relax during his training years in Cape Town. As of now, he turned his establishment into a real tasting laboratory, pushing the boundaries of his very technical cuisine. In his eyes, one ingredient offers a wide range of flavours that are just asking to be explored. The restaurant's signature dish thus unveils seven different methods of cooking tomatoes. This singular gastronomical experience is magnified by the cosy atmosphere and the pared-down decor that highlights the colourful work of art that takes centre stage in your plate. Between each course of the meal, keep an eye on the open-plan kitchen, where the “artists” are hard at work on your next dish. An exploration of new flavours, totally unheard of!

Muoki
38-4 Cheongdam-dong
Gangnam-gu
Seoul

+82 10 2948 4171

www.muoki.kr ﻿

Menu: from 60,000 KRW

content.title: Italian-style wine bar at Cucciolo Terrazza

introduction.small: Far from modernist settings, the Cucciolo Terrazza wine bar pays tribute to the traditional Italian trattoria in a vintage environment.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Italian-style wine bar at Cucciolo Terrazza

paragraphs.text:
Looking like a country house, Cucciolo Terrazza seems so far from Seoul. This wine bar located in the chic Gangnam district will give you the illusion of setting up home deep on Italian land to enjoy delicious antipasti. For a romantic outing or dinner with a small group of friends, the intimate and casual environment is the favourite spot of trendy Korean youth.
Take a seat in the patio on one of the white wicker chairs – in total harmony with flower-pattern iron-wrought tables – and enjoy some Rome-inspired dishes. Pizze, homemade pasta and sausage, as well as the fig bruschetta, star of the menu, will parade in vintage crockery covered with small pink painted flowers. Choose among the large wine selection (obviously imported from Italy) to pair – in moderation – in this harmonious moment worthy of genuine trattorie.

Cucciolo Terrazza
33 Seolleung-ro 152-gil
Cheongdam-dong
Gangnam-gu
Seoul

+82 10 3347 1571

Menu: antipasti from 3,000 KRW

content.title: Cloistered life at Hwagyesa Temple

introduction.small: For one night, live the life of a Buddhist monk. Practice meditation and other sacred rituals at Hwagyesa Temple in Seoul.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cloistered life at Hwagyesa Temple

paragraphs.text:
About 20 minutes from the Suyu station by foot, and close to metro line 4, the place is quiet, far from the crowds. In this haven of rest, Hwagyesa temple offers you to spend the night and take in Buddhist culture, adopted in South Korea more than 1,700 years ago. Practice meditation, which favours concentration, and take part in the morning ceremony dedicated to Buddha. You can also take on calligraphy and mandala lessons, followed by a traditional monk meal, consisting of rice and vegetables. Later during the day, witness a tea ceremony, which remains very important for all Asian societies. Out of the ordinary, this experience will give you a unique glimpse into cloistered life, which goal is to purify body and soul by way of contemplation and exploration into oneself.

Temple Hwagyesa
487 Suyu 1-dong
Gangbuk-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 902 2663

www.temple.bongeunsa.org

Night at the temple: 50 000 KRW

content.title: Hongdae, the neighbourhood where everything is possible

introduction.small: The kingdom of trendy Korean youth, Hongdae brings together everything that makes the soul of the city: meeting places, arts, shopping and nightlife.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hongdae, the neighbourhood where everything is possible

paragraphs.text:
Encircling Hongik University, the Hongdae district is a vibrant place teeming with students who have made it their home. Hongdae is full of trendy cafes, shops of all kinds, outdoor karaoke, independent artists and street performances. Here, freedom of expression is at every street corner and takes all forms.

In the evening, Korean and international students lay claim to the bars and clubs to dance and chat until dawn. At the weekend, the district of Hongdae is also the scene of a flea market where artists come to sell their creations: paintings, pottery, sculptures ... You will not be able to leave before discovering a treasure or two.

Hongdae is not an average neighbourhood. This is what makes its charm and propels it to the rank of a must-see in Seoul.

Hongik University
Mapo-gu District
Seoul

content.title: Thursday Party, the best bar for international rendezvous

introduction.small: At this multicultural address in Seoul, locals and foreigners mingle for a festive evening.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Thursday Party, the best bar for international rendezvous

paragraphs.text:
This bar is aptly named: ‘Thursday Party', a rendezvous for partygoers. Koreans and foreigners meet to talk, dance and have a night on the town where a festive atmosphere is assured.

 

On the brick wall the name of the bar appears in neon letters, the light is dimmed and the music loud. The bartenders serve cocktails of all kinds: Long Islands, Cosmos or Mojitos, but beer lovers will also find what they're looking for.

Everything is done to make sure you have a great evening and you will likely stay late into the night. Snacks can be served if you are hungry and you can play darts in teams or foosball or even beer pong, the version of ping pong in which you throw the ball into the glass on the other side of the net. Have fun!

Thursday Party
124-6 Itaewon 1(il)-dong
Yongsan-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 790 4222

Cocktails: from 4,000 KRW

content.title: Sigol Bapsang - in honour of banchans

introduction.small: A welcoming change of scenery in this small canteen dedicated to traditional dishes and objects of the past.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sigol Bapsang - in honour of banchans

paragraphs.text:
To reach this temple of banchans, go to Itaewon station (line 6) and take Exit 2. From there, walk about 10 minutes along the main street until you reach a large metal dog sculpture, then turn left. Stop when you get to a large orange sign. You're here. Bric-a-brac and vintage objects fill this tiny stand with happiness, which holds only a few tables. The feast begins: a festival of twenty banchans made of dried radish salad, soybean paste stew, fermented vegetables, and rice dough patties. These Korean ‘tapas' are served with white rice and a spicy soup. Open around the clock, this very rural canteen is a rare treat in a sprawling metropolis.

Sigol Bapsang
235 Itaewon-ro
Hannam-dong
Seoul

+82 (0)2 793 5390

Menu: around 12 000 KRW

content.title: Hotel Shinshin - Korean sobriety

introduction.small: A paradise for non-smokers, this recently renovated hotel is in the city's business district, and perfect for exploring Seoul.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Shinshin - Korean sobriety

paragraphs.text:
Four hundred metres from Namdaeum Bridge, formerly called Sungnyemum, and one of the eight gates that formed the walls of Seoul, and in the heart of hectic Myeongdong, business people and tourists enjoy the calm of the 75-room Shinshin. All rooms have bathroom and air-conditioning, and some more expensive, panoramic views of the city. As is customary here, there is a basket of courtesy toiletries in each room. It is nice to have breakfast at the bar where Thonet bistro chairs flirt with Korean vintage furniture. With its delicate colours and sober decoration, Shinshin is appreciated for its cleanliness and efficiency. Within this soothing modernity, Dinehall restaurant offers tasty Western cuisine. Hotel guests receive a 10% discount

Hotel Shinshin
17-5 Namdaemun-ro 5gil
Jung-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 2139 1000

www.hotel-shinshin.com

Rooms: from 109 000 KRW

content.title: The DMZ: the fissure between North and South

introduction.small: Less than 50 kilometres from Seoul, an ultra militarised zone divides Korea, marking a total break between two diametrically opposed forces.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The DMZ: the fissure between North and South

paragraphs.text:
North Korea and South Korea share a common history, like that of two feuding brothers.

South Korea embraces modernity and capitalism, while North Korea is the last vestige of the Cold War, and one of the world's most isolated and totalitarian countries. For more than 60 years, the demilitarised zone, which runs along the 248-km border between the two states of the peninsula, has offered an almost unreal tableau, where soldiers of the two countries face each other in the tensest atmosphere imaginable. Not respecting the codes and regulations results in a diplomatic incident.

Walking along the DMZ, you glimpse another Korea that of the ‘hermit kingdom' of Kim Jong-un and hear a kind of echo of the Berlin Wall before its fall, where the military are on constant patrol.

content.title: Noryangjin Fish Market

introduction.small: This covered market, which has existed for 80 years, houses almost 800 stalls, making it one of the biggest fish markets in Korea.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Noryangjin Fish Market

paragraphs.text:
Open continuously day and night, the Noryangjin Fish Market is a maze of some 6,000 square metres containing every imaginable type of seafood, dried fish, and crustacean, from the most common to the rarest, including salmon, sea cucumber, snapper, and stingray.

Wear a pullover and waterproof shoes on your pungent walk through the aisles the thermometer drops low, and water runs everywhere. For a glimpse of this market in a different light, come at two or three in the morning, when the wholesale auctions take place. The show is definitely worth getting up well before the sunrise for. Fish prices are affordable and the location offers an amazing feature: if during this exploration your appetite awakens, you can have your fish cooked for you in one of the many restaurants located just upstairs.

Noryangjin Fish Market
674 Nodeul-ro
Dongjak-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 2254 8000

www.susansijang.co.kr/

content.title: Thanks Nature Café: a natural rest stop in Hongdae

introduction.small: Very popular in South Korea for its innocence and sweetness, this original café has two sheep to keep you company.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Thanks Nature Café: a natural rest stop in Hongdae

paragraphs.text:
Seoul has its share of cafés, each more original than the other: dog bars, cat bars, Hello Kitty cafés concepts that have been exported to several other cities.

Here is the latest Korean novelty: a sheep bar! Thanks Nature Café, established in the student district of Hongdae, serves drinks in the company of the too-cute Lily and Milky. Housed in a building basement, amidst a wooden decor of plants and figurines bearing the likeness of the bar's stars, it offers snacks: waffles, toast, coffee, juice and tea, all reasonably priced. You have the choice between two rooms, one inside, the other outside, near the sheep pens. Big or small, come feed and cuddle your two new friends.

Thanks Nature Cafe
486 Seogyo-dong
Mapo-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 3357 470

www.facebook.com/TNcafe

Menu: around 5,000 KRW

content.title: Jogyesa Buddhist Temple: an urban oasis of spirituality

introduction.small: Escape the urban bustle for a few moments in an idyllic space of wellness and tranquillity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jogyesa Buddhist Temple: an urban oasis of spirituality

paragraphs.text:
Meditate in a peaceful setting under Napoleon pines more than five centuries old and marvel at frescoes and huge statutes of Buddha.

This is what awaits you at the historic temple of Jogyesa, built in 1910 in the heart of Seoul and surrounded by an amazing garden of many colours. This mecca of National Buddhism, open to everyone, will enable you to feel, deep within yourself, moments of true tranquillity. The sanctuary captures the essence of Korean Buddhism, established 1,700 years ago, and its Temple Stay and Temple Life programmes give visitors the chance to discover nothing less than the secret of inner peace and happiness. Take part in a tea ceremony or Chamseon meditation sessions, try a Buddhist meal or chat with a monk. During the Lotus Lantern Festival in May, at the approach of Buddha's birthday, bright lanterns are placed in the temple and a multitude of parades light up the streets.

Temple Jogyesa
55 Ujeongguk-ro
Jongno-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 7688 600

www.jogyesa.kr/user/english

content.title: Pilgyeong: taste the cuisine of the ancient royal court

introduction.small: In a corner of Gangnam there remains a relic of the past: a 500-year-old house in a magical setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pilgyeong: taste the cuisine of the ancient royal court

paragraphs.text:
Book a table at Pilgyeong to discover the oldest culinary traditions of Korea.

The former residence of the heirs of Prince Gwangpyeong, son of Sejong the Great, it was transformed in the late 1990s into a restaurant where the descendants of the royal line painstakingly reproduce authentic family recipes. The original architecture, complemented by an Asian garden, is extraordinary. Six menus are on offer, all consisting of 15 dishes, some of which are sure to baffle you. The server's level of English is basic, but the menu notes accurately describe the contents of your plates. To ensure intimacy, book a private room.

At the end of the meal, take your dessert into the park, and follow it with a walk.

Philkyungjae
739-1, Gwangpyeong-ro
Gangnam-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 4452 115

www.philkyungjae.co.kr/rain/index.php

Menu: around 20,000 KRW

content.title: The jimjilbangs: dip into Korean traditions

introduction.small: Abandon all ceremony, as one can only enter these baths in one's birthday suit.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The jimjilbangs: dip into Korean traditions

paragraphs.text:
Originally, Koreans went to jimjilbangs stone huts or halls where the temperatures rise to 120°C to purify themselves.

Today, these sweat lodges are an integral part of local life, with saunas and public baths, but also restaurants, gyms, and body treatment centres found within. There are thousands across the country, open round the clock every day of the year, and people come to either relax or hang out with their friends. At the heart of Seoul's Yongsan district, the Dragon Hill Spa offers an impressive choice. Forget all modesty: baths are separated for men and women, and nudity is not just appropriate, it's mandatory. Before jumping into one of the public baths,you enter the warmth of the Pine Wood Room (120°C) followed by the icy temperatures (5°C) of the Rock Icehouse. Do not hesitate to ask for a complete exfoliation treatment by an ajumma ‘aunt' in Korean.

Finish up in a fragrant meditation room shaped like an Egyptian pyramid, or a relaxation room with heated floor, and abandon yourself in complete serenity.

Dragon Hill Spa
40-713, Hangangno 3(sam)-ga
Yongsan-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 7920 001

www.dragonhillspa.com/en

content.title: Rakkojae: a guest house balancing elegance with tradition

introduction.small: A haven of peace that allows you to fully relax and to take a break in exceptional surroundings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rakkojae: a guest house balancing elegance with tradition

paragraphs.text:
A traditional hanok transformed into a guest house and renovated in 2003 by a renowned master carpenter, this intimate place perfectly reflects the elegance of Korean culture.

With four rooms decorated according to tradition, it is a real gem for those seeking tranquillity. Sleep on a futon on a natural jade floor, relax in a wooden tub, and delight in the typical Korean dishes as they are brought to you. In such a scene it is easy to imagine ancient times when sages came here to meditate. The hosts are attentive, sincere, personable, and refined. Have breakfast on the patio beside a lotus flower pond, attend a tea ceremony, or relax in a traditional, clay-walled sauna.

Rakkojae
218 Gahoe-dong
Jongno-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 742 3410

www.rkj.co.kr

Rooms: from 275,000 KRW

content.title: Masizzim: simplicity revisited

introduction.small: An accessible but effective concept, both traditional and modern.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Masizzim: simplicity revisited

paragraphs.text:
Located in the trendy Gangnam area, Masizzim illustrates a paradox of contemporary South Korea: attachment to traditions combined with a continual search for modernity.

Simple dishes rooted in local culinary tradition are the house specialty, such as a stew of beef ribs or pork drizzled with secret sauces. Conversely, the contemporary side is reflected in a decidedly minimalist décor, which honours the dynamism of Korean design.

Mixing genres is the key to an inviting introduction to Korean cuisine.

Masizzim
136 Dongsung-gil
Jongno-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 7434 508

www.masizzim.co.kr/main

Menu: around 22,000 KRW

content.title: Stroll and shop in Gangnam

introduction.small: If you've taken a vow of worship to the fashion gods, then this shopping temple, which boasts all the latest trends, is for you.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Stroll and shop in Gangnam

paragraphs.text: Gangnam, which means ‘south of the river', is one of the most exclusive and modern neighbourhoods in the South Korean capital. Popularised by the worldwide hit single by Psy ‘Gangnam Style', this laid-back district of Seoul is dynamic and touristic, and the perfect place to go on a shopping expedition. In a trendy and artistic atmosphere, Gangnam specialises in luxury and independent designer goods, and an impressive variety of sightseeing activities. There are high-end hotels, a casino, an aquarium, the Seoul Arts Center, and even a kimchi museum. Take a ride along the Sinsa-dong Garosu-gil Road, where cafés and designer shops coexist in an original and captivating atmosphere. For a more exclusive atmosphere, steer yourself to Apgujeong, which hosts major luxury brands, such as Chanel, Louis Vuitton, and Gucci. End your tour at the Seorae village, which is filled with bakeries, cafés, and many Western restaurants.

content.title: Namdaemun: the market for bargain hunters

introduction.small: Genuine and popular, its endless alleys mark the start of a complete change of scenery.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Namdaemun: the market for bargain hunters

paragraphs.text:
This 600 year-old market on Namdaemun sijang street near the Great South Gate is Korea's .

True treasure trove, with nearly 10,000 businesses and merchants of all kinds. A legacy of the Joseon Dynasty, its immensity and the incredible diversity of products make its streets an unrivalled locale for eye candy and people watching. The colourful stalls sell everything under the sun clothing, accessories, electronic products, handicrafts, and traditional items. At night, the big vendors open their gates, amplifying the excitement of the place. And because these purchases will have awakened your appetite, the many food-kiosk merchants will be delighted to introduce you to a wide variety of dishes that are sometimes surprising but always delicious.

Namdaemun
21 Namdaemunsijang 4-gil
Jung-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 7532 805

content.title: The Plaza: a hotel at the crossroads

introduction.small: Easy to access and extremely well located, this institution offers a perfect marriage of history and modernity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Plaza: a hotel at the crossroads

paragraphs.text:
Located in the historical centre of Seoul, near the business district, the hotel has basement access to the subway and a shopping centre.

Italian designer Guido Ciompi has completely redesigned the site with clean lines, walls and furniture in a colour palette of white and rosewood, and a bravado mix of materials stone, paper, leather, and velvet. In the Royal Suite, modern lines have given way to a much more posh atmosphere. A business centre,featuring rooms with three different capacities, is available for guests who need meeting places.

The rooms are a bit small, but note the excellent service and up-to-the-minute technology. In winter, enjoy the skating rink right in front, on the square of the City Hall.

The Plaza
119 Sogong-ro
Jung-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 771 2200

www.hoteltheplaza.com/eng/index.jsp

Rooms: from 208,000 KRW

content.title: The Seonjeongneung burial grounds: UNESCO World Heritage Site

introduction.small: A site loaded with history and poetry, enjoyed in the morning by those who come to exercise.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Seonjeongneung burial grounds: UNESCO World Heritage Site

paragraphs.text:
The most emblematic figures of the Joseon Dynasty are entombed in a forest park in the heart of Gangnam.

After 519 years of rule, from the 14th to the 20th century, the royal line is anchored deeply in the landscape of Korea. During your walk you will discover majestic tombs, those of the ninth king Seonjong, his third wife Jeonghyeon and Jungjong, 11th monarch of the Joseon Dynasty, marked by stone animals, symbols of royal power and protectors from evil spirits. Seonjong marked a prosperous era in Korea. Under his reign, great cultural, political, and economic advances we're made. In autumn, the landscape is especially beautiful. We meet, at bends in the paths, elderly people, who come early in the morning to take advantage of this haven of peace.

To help you to understand the scope of these relics, a small museum recounts the history of these kings, and those in the three tombs between here and Gangnam.

Tombes Seonjeongneung
1 Seolleung-ro 100-gil
Gangnam-gu
Seoul

+82 2 568 1291

www.cha.go.kr

content.title: Rakkojae, une maison d'hôte entre élégance et tradition

introduction.small: A haven of peace that allows you to fully relax and to take a break in exceptional surroundings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rakkojae, une maison d'hôte entre élégance et tradition

paragraphs.text:
A traditional hanok transformed into a guesthouse and renovated in 2003 by a renowned master carpenter, this intimate place perfectly reflects the elegance of Korean culture. With four rooms decorated according to tradition, it is a real gem for those seeking tranquility. Sleep on a futon on a natural jade floor, relax in a wooden tub, and delight in the typical Korean dishes as they are brought to you. In such a scene it is easy to imagine ancient times when sages came here to meditate. The hosts are attentive, sincere, personable, and refined. Have breakfast on the patio beside a lotus flower pond, attend a tea ceremony, or relax in a traditional, clay-walled sauna.


Rakkojae

218 Gahoe-dong

Jongno-gu

Seoul


+82 (0)2 742 3410


www.rkj.co.kr


Rooms: from 275,000 KRW

content.title: Park Hyatt Seoul: for a perfect stay

introduction.small: A bubble of comfort and refinement in the heart of the Korean megalopolis.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Park Hyatt Seoul: for a perfect stay

paragraphs.text:
This hotel offers an ideal location and impeccable service in the bustling business district of Gangnam.

Combining neutral but elegant tones and an attention to detail, everything here is beautiful, and the spacious rooms havemagnificent views. The granite bathroom in the Presidential Suite gives way to an unstructured design gem, in the middle of which stands a huge tub. The windows stretch from floor to a ceiling height of 3.4 metres, offering a stunning view of the city. Climb to the Lounge to watch the sunset and stop off at Cornerstone, where exquisitely prepared meat is the specialty. In the basement, the subdued atmosphere of the piano bar is guaranteed to relax. In addition to all this, an especially unique experience awaits you on the 24th floor: a dive into the pool, which appears to be suspended above the city, providing a moment you're not likely to forget anytime soon.

Park Hyatt Seoul
606, Teheran-ro
Gangnam-gu,
Seoul

+82 (0)2 2016 1234

www.hyatt.com/en-US/hotel/south-korea/park-hyatt-seoul/selph

Rooms: from 355,000 KRW

content.title: Sohsul Hotel: a free electron in Seoul

introduction.small: Rooms in trompe-l'œil and an ultramodern interior a real work of art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sohsul Hotel: a free electron in Seoul

paragraphs.text:
The 3D checkerboard carpet in the entrance is the first surprise. The space is dark but lush with vegetation.

With its brick marble or pure white walls, Sohsul is, to say the least, unusual. Set on the south bank of the Han River, a few metres from the Nambu Bus Terminal, the hotel is excellently located, allowing you to walk easily to all corners of the capital. This cocoon offers 12 charming rooms and suites of very spacious urban design. Go for the ‘Spa and Pool' room, which has a private pool, the ‘Dome' suite, decorated with old stones, or the ‘Illusion' Suite, which should shake your bearings with its optical effects.

The service is very friendly, although the staff has some difficulties in English.

Hôtel Sohsul
Bangbae 4(sa)-dong
Seocho-gu,
Seoul

+82 (0)2 5070 505

www.snowhotel.co.kr/en

Rooms: from 150,000 KRW

content.title: The Trick Eye Museum: optical illusions and artistic interaction

introduction.small: If you thought you'd seen everything in Seoul, think again!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Trick Eye Museum: optical illusions and artistic interaction

paragraphs.text:
Located in the centre of the artistic Hongdae area of ​​Seoul, the Trick Eye uses trompe-l'œil techniques to great effect. Optical illusions, 3D versions of famous paintings, and interactivity are at the heart of the visit. The first part of the museum takes you literally inside Pere Borrell del Caso and Leonardo da Vinci's paintings, or into the arms of Superman, or climbing trees with koalas. In the second part is the Ice Museum, where ice structures and slides will entertain and awaken your inner child. The third section is for adults only: it uses the same techniques of optical illusion but for purely ‘erotic' purposes. Meanwhile, children can play in the fourth part, Carnival, which is filled with games and rides. An entertaining and interactive sensory experience for everyone.

Trick Eye Museum
357-1, Seogyo-dong
Mapo-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 3144 6300

www.trickeye.com/seoul

content.title: Enjoy the fresh fish you just bought at Noryangjin Fish Market

introduction.small: Come walk the aisles of this vast covered market to select the fish of your choice and enjoy it on the spot.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Enjoy the fresh fish you just bought at Noryangjin Fish Market

paragraphs.text:
More than just a visit to a market, a stroll through Noryangjin Fish Market allows you to explore a unique element of Korean cuisine.

The choice is vast in this labyrinth of fish and shellfish. Select your own delicacy directly out of the aquarium or taken from the stalls of crushed ice. Then climb to the second floor and choose,from among the many on offer, the restaurant that inspires you the most (JinnamSushi enjoys an excellent reputation). The chef will then take your catch of the day and grill, steam, or fry it, or carve it up and serve it as sashimi. For adventurous taste buds, try the live octopus. To consume, follow this technique: pick up the octopus head with your chopsticks, wrap the body by hand all around, dip it quickly in the sauce and enjoy!

Noryangjin Fish Market
674 Nodeul-ro
Dongjak-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 2254 8000

www.susansijang.co.kr/

Menu: depends on the fish you buy

content.title: Hadongkwan: six decades of sincere and delicious cuisine

introduction.small: Run by the same family for more than 60 years, this restaurant still serves the best traditional soup in town.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hadongkwan: six decades of sincere and delicious cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Every day at noon, locals and tourists get in line for a table in order to taste the best Korean soup in the capital.

Ms. YH Kim, head chef for more than 40 years, always buys from the same suppliers to ensure that everything is flawless and absolutely unique. Open every day at lunchtime, the restaurant closes its doors when they run out of ingredients. Just so you know: since 1939, they have never closed later than 4:30 p.m. It's a simple formula: choose a normal or special bowl, you pay, and you take a seat. Minutes later, your bowl comes with a bit of kimchi.

The barley tea is especially delicious and is said to help digestion, but you can only drink it standing up,because seats here are worth their weight in gold.

Hadongkwan
10-4, Myeongdong, 1(il-)ga
Jung-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 7765 656

www.hadongkwan.com

Menu: around 12,000 KRW

content.title: Myeongdong: a shopping paradise

introduction.small: Whether you have shopping fever or not, just experiencing this place, located in the heart of Seoul, is alone worth the visit.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Myeongdong: a shopping paradise

paragraphs.text:
A consumer extravaganza awaits you at the heart of impressive diversity in a lively district.

In this commercial enclave, large banners of Korean cosmetics and fashion brands share pride of place with luxury flagships and more affordable brands. A temple of outdoor shopping, it buzzes until late at night, its streets crowded with shops, restaurants, and cafés. Myeongdong is not just limited to luxury and refinement it finds space for local designers and international brands, as well. Lose yourself in the small streets and stroll among the many stands that combine Korean food, more diversified products, and gadgets. Linger until evening, when the lights come on and the music starts, and a completely different atmosphere settles into place.

content.title: Hotel La Casa: a sparklingaddress close to the bustle of Gangnam

introduction.small: Hotel La Casa is a small, quiet, and cosy nest that will give you the feeling of not having left home.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel La Casa: a sparklingaddress close to the bustle of Gangnam

paragraphs.text:
A standout. Not as spacious as the more renowned hotels, but the warm, familiar, and personal service more than makes up for it.

The facade is impressive, but of sober design. This charming address, next to the Casa Mia furniture and decoration shop, offers a relaxing stay. The entrance way is so inviting that it feels like you've entered a very comfortable bookshop. The rooms are simply but tastefully decorated, with rounded lines and soft colours, unadorned yet in tune with the times, imagined by the designers of the Casa Mia brand. Its location, within walking distance of Garosu-gil, is ideal.

The hotel is located in the famous shopping area of ​​Gangnam, which is known for its baobab trees along the streets, and where there are numerous art galleries, restaurants, and cafés.

Hôtel La Casa
527-2 Sinsa-dong
Gangnam-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 5460 088

la-casa.seoultophotels.com

Rooms: from 150,000 KRW

content.title: Imperial Palace Boutique Hotel: Pop-art comfort

introduction.small: From its multicoloured facade to the swings in the lobby, the ultra-modern décor of the hotel offers an artistic stay in a vibrant atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Imperial Palace Boutique Hotel: Pop-art comfort

paragraphs.text:
Opened in 2010, this contemporary hotel is a one-of-a-kind jewel. Ultramodern and even futuristic in design, the décor in each of the 133 rooms has been individually conceived, with special emphasis on works of pop art. Brightened by white walls, high windows, and large mirrors, the colourful paintings bring an original touch and extra eye-opening pop. The hotel is an art gallery, which allows you to perfect your artistic sensibilities while enjoying ideal comfort.

The service is friendly and attentive, and the two restaurants offer excellent Western dishes. A unique and exciting concept, Imperial Palace Boutique Hotel has risen to the highest ranks. It is a great choice for anyone looking for comfort and modernity in an unconventional setting.

Imperial Palace Boutique Hotel
737-32 Hannam-dong
Yongsan-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 3702 8000

www.ipboutiquehotel.com

Rooms: from 220,000 KRW

content.title: The Imperial Palace: all the pomp of an ancient palace

introduction.small: The perfect alternative to the city's contemporary hotels.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Imperial Palace: all the pomp of an ancient palace

paragraphs.text:
The Imperial Palace is far from the bustle, in the new part of Seoul.

Nearby are Garosu and Gangnam-gil, two neighbourhoods known for their rows of shops, restaurants, bars, and art galleries. Antiques and paintings from England and France adorn the walls of this hotel, which has the elegance of an old palace. The entrance is spectacular, with its Victorian-inspired fountain, and helps set the hotel off as an alternative to the modern-design hotels of Seoul. The rooms are spacious and the luxurious spa with its huge Japanese-style tub, is extremely inviting.

This is also one of the few hotels in the capital to have an outdoor pool and also offers access to a large indoor pool. The staff is extremely helpful and all speak perfect English.

Imperial Palace
640 Eonju-ro
Gangnam-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 3440 8000

www.imperialpalace.co.kr/eng

Rooms: from 200,000 KRW

content.title: Dongdaemun Design Plaza: the emblem of design in Korea

introduction.small: Known as DDP, this architectural jewel, designed by the famous Iraqi-British architect ZahaHadid, stands like a UFO on the cityscape.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dongdaemun Design Plaza: the emblem of design in Korea

paragraphs.text:
Seoul, crowned the world capital of design by UNESCO in 2010, now has too many incredibly revolutionary structures in contemporary style to count. The DDP, the largest building of asymmetric architecture in the world, is one of the best examples of ultra-modernity in the megalopolis. Located in the historic Jongno District, this complex serves as an exhibition space and cultural events centre. It also hosts a design museum, a hall of arts, a shopping and conference space, and a design laboratory. Symbolising the country's future, the DDP also embodies a connection with the history of the nation because of its location (the site houses many ancient relics), and by its 30,000 square-metre park, which is structured along the principles of traditional Korean gardens. It is the largest asymmetrical building in the world. Spread over 85,000 sqm, it counts 7 floors. Its overall design looks like a UFO, or what architect Zaha Hadid calls a “metonymical landscape”. Recalling water flowing by, the DDP bridges the gap between Korean traditions and the city's constant evolution.

Dongdaemun Design Plaza
281, Eulji-ro
Jongno-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 2153 0000

www.ddp.or.kr/

content.title: Bongeunsa: peaceful haven for 1,200 years

introduction.small: A sphere of serenity in the heart of the Gangnam district, Bongeunsa temple takes you to the crossroads of Buddhist and Korean heritages.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bongeunsa: peaceful haven for 1,200 years

paragraphs.text:
More than just a religious shrine, Bongeunsa is full of pagodas, Buddhas, and other hidden treasures. Visiting the temple, where thousands of ceiling lanterns illuminate the incredibly meticulous artistic details etched into the walls, is a dizzying journey through Korean culture and history. Admire the paintings dating back centuries in the main lodge, enjoy the tea ceremony, rejuvenate yourself in the fresh air of the gardens, and finish facing the gigantic Buddha statue.

The ambience is serene, infused with fragrant aroma of tea and punctuated by the sound of the drums that accompany prayers this is a great escape beyond time and space. Let yourself be caught up in the culture seon, or ‘zen' of this mystical place. For those who want to push the Buddhist experience to its peak, the temple offers the opportunity to sleep there for one night and follow the monastic routine.

Bongeunsa Temple
531 Bongeunsa-ro
Gangnam-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 3218 4800

www.bongeunsa.org

content.title: The Shilla Seoul: a night in a five star resort

introduction.small: Rated as the best hotel in Seoul, The Shilla promises perfect comfort and fool-proof luxury.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Shilla Seoul: a night in a five star resort

paragraphs.text:
Anyone fortunate enough to stay in this prestigious hotel is sure to blissfully enjoy the high-quality services of the institution.

Sober and modern, with a discreet and attentive staff, everything comes together to create a sumptuous setting. The newly renovated rooms are beautiful and bright, with excellent beds and a contemporary bathroom with spacious bath. Request a room with a view of the N Seoul Tower and enjoy the beautiful sunset. This 23-storey complex offers two swimming pools, a very functional gym, and a spa where you can be introduced to the tradition of Korean bathing. The refined restaurant also contributes to the reputation of the place. A little out of the city centre, the hotel remains easily accessible by taxi.

Shilla Seoul
249 Dongho-ro
Jung-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 2233 3131

www.m.shilla.net/seoul/index.do

Rooms: from 250,000 KRW

content.title: The Conrad: luxury in the heart of the business district

introduction.small: Considered one of the world's best hotels, this bastion of luxury offers spectacular views of the city's skyscrapers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Conrad: luxury in the heart of the business district

paragraphs.text:
Located west of Seoul and overlooking the Yeouido subway and IFC mall, which it is connected to by a lift, The Conrad offers a magical view of the Han River.

The spacious rooms rare in Seoul in wood and marble, are illuminated by soft filtered light. Quiet at night, away from the city centre and main tourist sites, it hosts mainly business travellers. Ask for a room on the top of the tower, on the river side, and you'll wake up to the most amazing spectacle. The staff is very attentive, and the breakfast buffet offers a plethora of choices.

Take the opportunity to go for a run or stroll along the river and ascend to the 37th floor for a 180° view of Seoul.

The Conrad
10 Gukjegeumyung-ro
Yeongdeungpo-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 6137 7000

www.conradhotels3.hilton.com/en/hotels/south-korea/conrad-seoul-SELCICI/index.html

Rooms: from 220,000 KRW

content.title: Bar Kloud: perched above the roofs of Gangnam

introduction.small: On the 21St floor of the Hotel Mercure Seoul Ambassador Gangnam Sodowe is a small New York-style bar that offers astonishing views of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bar Kloud: perched above the roofs of Gangnam

paragraphs.text:
Why not go far, far outand up for an evening ? Comfortably installed on the terrace of Bar Kloud, you will be amazed to discover another face of the Korean capital.

Up among the skyscrapers, staring into the horizon and the thousand and one lights of the wealthy district of Gangnam. The panoramic view is perfect for watching the sun set over Seoul.

This exceptional place in a modern setting is not content to just provide a feast your eyes: a wide range of cocktails made by internationally known professionals is offered to stimulate your other senses.

Bar Kloud
10 Teheran-ro
25-gilYeoksam 1(il)-dong
Gangnam-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 2050 6035

www.facebook.com/rooftopbarKLOUD?fref=t

Drinks: around 6,000 KRW

content.title: Cheonggyecheon: a soothing stroll in the heart of the megalopolis

introduction.small: Escape the hectic pace of the city on this charming walk among spectacular murals and fountains.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cheonggyecheon: a soothing stroll in the heart of the megalopolis

paragraphs.text:
Spanning six kilometres, this artificial waterway was completely renovated in 2005.

The river and its 22 bridges are favourite strolling grounds for Koreans and tourists alike. During the day, enjoy the art of five renowned contemporary artists on the Wall of Culture at Ogansumun Bridge, which sports colourful murals more than 10 metres in length. At dusk, the river becomes even more charming. Take in the fresh air on the quays and admire the reflection of the landscape on the water and the fountains, especially the dynamic colour projections on the arches under Ogansugyo Bridge.

Cheonggyecheon-ro
Sangwangsimni-dong
Jongno-gu
Séoul

+82 (0)2 2290 7111

www.sisul.or.kr

content.title: Congdu; at the crossroads of culinary authenticity and modernity

introduction.small: Creativity, innovation, and tradition are at the heart of the dishes served in a restaurant that invites you on a culinary journey.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Congdu; at the crossroads of culinary authenticity and modernity

paragraphs.text:
Finding this place near Deoksung Palace and the US Embassy can be difficult, but don't give up. Every dish at Congdu starts with the same component: soybean.

The creativity and innovative spirit of the restaurant staff turns this into everything from sauce to tofu ice cream. Employing techniques from French gastronomy and molecular cuisine, the chefs bring a modern touch to traditional Korean flavours. Try the raw blue crab, tofu tiramisu, pork simmeredfor 48 hours or 15-year-old beef sirloin marinated in soy sauce. The dishes as pretty as their names are evocative.

When the weather permits, the roof terrace is open, giving way to a starry sky. The atmosphere is quiet and sophisticated, the service efficient and attentive.

Congdu
116-1, Deoksugung-gil
Jung-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 7227 002

www.congdu.com/main/ko

Menu: around 36,800 KRW

content.title: Mingles: an explosion of flavours at the crossroads of various influences

introduction.small: A fusion of Korean, French, Japanese, and Spanish cuisines, this restaurant offers a taste experience of outstanding quality.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mingles: an explosion of flavours at the crossroads of various influences

paragraphs.text:
Run by Mr. Kang, former head of the famous Nobu restaurants in Dubai and Miami, Mingles combines elegance, creativity, modernity, and local flavours to perfection.

Located in the Gangnam neighbourhood, the restaurant has a unique five-course menu for lunch and dinner. Throughout the tasting, from foie gras with seafood to the creme brulee, all accompanied by Korean fermented sauces, this gastronomic journey will take you to unexpected territories. The wood and stone decor is chic and trendy. The service is as careful and attentive as the cuisine absolutely perfect. For here, every element is thought through, with even each garnishing approaching a work of art.

An exceptional dining experience not to be missed !

Mingles
94-9 Nonhyen-dong
Gangnam-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 515 7306

www.restaurant-mingles.com

Menu: from 75,000 KRW

content.title: Gahoe Museum: voyage to ancient Korea

introduction.small: Tucked away in a small alley, this hanok (traditional house) converted into a museum is a must-see for all lovers of ancient Korean art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gahoe Museum: voyage to ancient Korea

paragraphs.text:
Despite its small size, this museum constitutes a real trompe-l'œil, because it contains some 2,000 paintings, amulets, and books, each worthy of careful analysis, that together provide a comprehensive overview of centuries of Korean history and culture.

Art workshops are part of the programme, teaching traditional Korean art techniques like fan painting, woodcut printing, and amulet stamping. A delicious cup of green tea awaits at the end of the visit.

Musée Gahoe
17 Bukchon-ro 12-gil
Jongno-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 7410 466

www.gahoemuseum.org

content.title: Lab XXIV: a bold and refined gastronomic voyage

introduction.small: Unique culinary creations and innovative cuisine inone of the best gourmet restaurants in Seoul.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lab XXIV: a bold and refined gastronomic voyage

paragraphs.text:
Famous for his stint at the Burj Al Arab in Dubai, the young and talented chef Edward Kwon decided to name his new project Lab XXIV. ‘Lab' for the experimental side the owner has transformed the restaurant into a real gastronomic laboratory and ‘XXIV' for the culinary obsession that haunts his mind round the clock, 24/7, 365 days a year.

Presented with refinement and delicacy, his creations will transport you into a world where flavours and aromas combine remarkably, creating contemporary cuisine as diverse as it is colourful. Each dish is unique, mixing rare and exquisite ingredients, while the menu, accompanied by the chef's descriptions and explanations, is regularly renewed. A full wine list complements this restaurant of modern and chic décor that make it ideal for a romantic getaway or a celebratory event.

Lab XXIV
89-5 Cheongdam-dong
Gangnam-gu
Seoul

+ 82 (0)2 5114 523

www.labxxiv.com

Menu: from 140,000 KRW

content.title: To Sok Chon: a felicitous blend of simplicity and tradition

introduction.small: Discover the secrets of authentic Korean cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: To Sok Chon: a felicitous blend of simplicity and tradition

paragraphs.text:
A few steps from Gyeongbokgung Palace, this restaurant is particularly popular with locals.

But don't be fooled by the apparent simplicity of the place, because behind these doors stands one of the country's temples of traditional cuisine. Sit around a table and enjoy this perfect opportunity to discover the unique flavours of two key Korean ingredients: ginseng and chicken. Ginseng chicken soup, delicately flavoured, is the star dish, but the fermented cabbage kimchi is equally spectacular. Accompany the meal with a ginseng wine for a more in-depth discovery of local culinary customs.

The restaurant can fill up very quickly, but the service is fast and the wait never lasts too long.

To Sok Chon
5 Jahamun-ro 5-gil
Jongno-gu
Seoul

+ 82 (0)2 7377 444

www.tosokchon.com/index.php?lug=en

Menu: around 15,000 KRW

content.title: Banyan Tree Club & Spa: a modern and refined getaway amid natural splendours

introduction.small: Nestled on Mount Namsan, Banyan Tree offers a harmonious blend of luxury, modernity, and nature in a dazzling landscape.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Banyan Tree Club & Spa: a modern and refined getaway amid natural splendours

paragraphs.text:
Whether looking out on the clear water of the Han River, the breath-taking view of the capital, or the idyllic mountains, each room at this luxurious hotel reveals stunning vistas through its huge windows.

While decorated in Korean style, the mix of the modern and the rustic creates a very fashion-conscious and elegant atmosphere. For athletes, this green oasis also has a golf course. Stop in at the sauna before relaxing in a bath that looks out on a dazzling vision of natural beauty. Service is friendly and the four restaurants offer an impressive variety of gourmet dishes.

Located just ten minutes from downtown Seoul, this is the perfect place for any enthusiast looking for a quiet stopover in a stunning natural setting.

Banyan Tree Club & Spa
60, Jangchungdan-ro
Jung-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 2250 8000

www.banyantreespa.com

Rooms: from 420,000 KRW

content.title: Gahoe Museum: voyage to ancient Korea

introduction.small: Tucked away in a small alley, this hanok (traditional house) converted into a museum is a must-see for all lovers of ancient Korean art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gahoe Museum: voyage to ancient Korea

paragraphs.text:
Despite its small size, this museum constitutes a real trompe-l'oeil, because it contains some 2,000 paintings, amulets, and books, each worthy of careful analysis, that together provide a comprehensive overview of centuries of Korean history and culture. Art workshops are part of the programme, teachingtraditional Korean art techniques like fan painting, woodcut printing, and amulet stamping. A delicious cup of green tea awaits at the end of the visit.


Musée Gahoe

17 Bukchon-ro 12-gil

Jongno-gu

Seoul


+82 (0)2 7410 466


www.gahoemuseum.org

content.title: N Seoul Tower and Namsan Mountain, a splendid panorama

introduction.small: Known as the Mountain of Lovers don't forget to hang a lock at the top to seal your love forever!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: N Seoul Tower and Namsan Mountain, a splendid panorama

paragraphs.text:
Enjoy first the greenery and large Imperial bronze statues of Namsan Park a marked contrast with the modernity of the capital. Climbing the 262 metres from the hill to the base of the tower is arduous and best left to the athletes.

Take the high-tech cable car instead, which takes a mere 30 seconds and offers impressive views of the city and the tower, especially when it is illuminated at night. Officially open to the public since 1980, the tower rises 238 metres from the summit, and its highest point is 479 metres above sea level. Numerous revolving restaurants, cafés and shops are on the different floors, but the impressive view alone is worth the visit.

N Seoul Tower
105 Namsangongwon-gil
Yongsan-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 3455 9277

www.nseoultower.co.kr/eng

content.title: Bukhansan National Park

introduction.small: A breath of fresh air just outside the capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bukhansan National Park

paragraphs.text:
Ideal for a Sunday getaway, Bukhansan National Park is popular with Seoulites.

It is best in the autumn, when the vegetation takes on a coat of shimmering colour. This green expanse in the heart of the largest Korean metropolis is also a place of worship. A succession of temples and Buddha statues line the path to the top. Enjoy a moment of peace and healing in Geumsansa Temple, and admire the door of the old fortress Bukhansan. Go all the way to the summit of Peak Jaunbong the view of Seoul below is breath-taking.

A well marked trail is the easiest way to the top, but if in doubt, ask at the reception about the best route to follow.

Bukhansan National Park
262 Bogukmun-ro
Seongbuk-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 909 0497

www.english.knps.or.kr

content.title: Deoksugung Palace : a former royal city

introduction.small: A journey from traditional architecture to Western neo-modernism.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Deoksugung Palace : a former royal city

paragraphs.text:
The smallest of the five major palaces of Seoul, Deoksugung is nonetheless unique for its harmonious blend of Joseon era and Western neoclassical architecture.

The ‘Palace of the virtuous life' is a quiet haven whose gardens are the perfect place for a moment of meditation, all the while admiring the sleek lines of traditional architecture. Don't miss the changing of the Royal Guard, which brings together a multitude of costumes and rituals, all at the heart of the traditions and protocols of the Joseon ‘hermit kingdom' dynasty. The main building, Junghwajeon, has had two lives: formerly consisting of two floors, it was engulfed in flames in 1904, before being rebuilt two years later.

Palais Deoksugung
99, Sejong-daero
Jung-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 7719 951

content.title: Lotte World: dive into the heart of a magical bubble

introduction.small: A recreational paradise, Lotte World takes you on a multi-faceted adventure.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lotte World: dive into the heart of a magical bubble

paragraphs.text:
The largest indoor amusement park in the world, Lotte World is the perfect getaway for families, friends, and couples.

Split into two parks, one indoor and one outdoor, one slogan prevails here have fun because the scenery will transport you into a world of wild adventures. In the evening everything is lit up, and skaters cover the ice. If it's too chilly and you're eager for thrills, try the ‘Big Loop', or climb to the top of the ‘Gyro Drop' for a 70-metre free-fall. Between the replica of the Trevi Fountain and the carousel, take in a cruise to ‘Magic Island'. And if you're with kids, don't miss the musical performances.

If the queues are long, drop in on the Folk Museum, a very entertaining way to discover the history of Korea

Lotte World
240 Olympic-ro
Songpa-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 1661 2000

www.lotteworld.com

content.title: Le palais Gyeongbogung, une immersion dans la vie de château

introduction.small:
Dating from the Joseon Dynasty, Gyeongbogung Palace is also called the ‘greatly blessed palace of the sky'.


.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le palais Gyeongbogung, une immersion dans la vie de château

paragraphs.text:
This majestic building, built in 1395 and repeatedly destroyed by the Japanese occupations—but rebuilt each time—celebrates the greatness of the nation. The largest of the five dynastic palaces of the city, it was the king’s residence and the place from whence he sent out his royal edicts to his subjects. Nestled in the heart of the city, the royal complex is surrounded on both sides by mountains protecting it from the wind. Several buildings can be visited, including the Hyangwonjeong pavilion, erected in the middle of a lake, and Gyeonghoeru pavilion, with its 48 pillars. Young Koreans in traditional dress (hanbok) wander about the grounds, and they’re usually open to having their picture taken. At the entrance, guards, utterly immobile, wear the same uniforms as their predecessors in the distant past. Be sure to catch the changing of the guard, accompanied by the sound of drums, and finish your day with a tour of the National Folk Museum.


Palais Gyeongbogung


161 Sajik-ro

Jongno-gu,

Seoul


+82 (0)2 3700 3900


www.royalpalace.go.kr/html/eng/main/main.jsp

content.title: The Bukchon district : escape into another time

introduction.small: North of Seoul, not far from the bustling city and its huge towers, is an enclave of tranquillity, combining history and architecture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Bukchon district : escape into another time

paragraphs.text:
This neighbourhood is actually a 600-year-old hamlet, a rare vestige of the megalopolis's past.

Located halfway between the famous palaces of Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung, the ‘hanok' village of Bukchon holds many secrets. Its renovated houses of stone and wood were once the residences of the Korean aristocracy. They have retained their authenticity and are marvellously picturesque and romantic. Wander the narrow lanes and watch the beautiful ‘sea of rooftops' in curved black-and-white tiles that adorn the houses of the neighbourhood. Make sure you wear the right shoes, as the hills can be steep. The skyscrapers in the distance offer a beautiful contrast.

You can enrich your program by adding visits to Bukchon's many museums, restaurants, cafés, workshops, art galleries, and shops. And to prolong your immersion, why not visit a house and enjoy a cup of tea?

Bukchon Hanok Village
Gye-dong
Jongno-gu,
Seoul

+82 (0)2 2133 1371

www.bukchon.seoul.go.kr

content.title: Transform yourself into a K-pop star at the SMT own Coex Artium

introduction.small: Discover a surprising and extravagant world that you will not soon forget.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Transform yourself into a K-pop star at the SMT own Coex Artium

paragraphs.text:
K-pop, short for Korean Pop, a mixture of pop, electro, R & B, hip-hop, and rock, is hugely popular throughout Asia. SMTown explores every nook and cranny of this musical movement.

The theme park invites you to dive into a very particular universe, where derivatives are taken to the extreme and pure entertainment is the only concern. The experience is complete and original, with videos, holograms, multiple accessories, and other interactive workshops revealing the biggest names in K-pop and all that surrounds them.

Whether you're a K-pop insider or novice, this unusual space will undoubtedly arouse your curiosity and introduce you to one of the most fascinating phenomena of contemporary Korean culture.

SMTown Coex Artium
513, Yeongdongdae-ro
Gangnam-gu
Seoul

+82 (0)2 6002 5300

www.coexmall.com

content.title: Gyeongbogung Palace : immerse yourself in castle life

introduction.small:
Dating from the Joseon Dynasty, Gyeongbogung Palace is also called the ‘greatly blessed palace of the sky'.
.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gyeongbogung Palace : immerse yourself in castle life

paragraphs.text:
This majestic building, built in 1395 and repeatedly destroyed by the Japanese occupations but rebuilt each time celebrates the greatness of the nation.

The largest of the five dynastic palaces of the city, it was the king's residence and the place from whence he sent out his royal edicts to his subjects. Nestled in the heart of the city, the royal complex is surrounded on both sides by mountains protecting it from the wind. Several buildings can be visited, including the Hyangwonjeong pavilion, erected in the middle of a lake, and Gyeonghoeru pavilion, with its 48 pillars. Young Koreans in traditional dress (hanbok) wander about the grounds, and they're usually open to having their picture taken. At the entrance, guards, utterly immobile, wear the same uniforms as their predecessors in the distant past.

Be sure to catch the changing of the guard, accompanied by the sound of drums, and finish your day with a tour of the National Folk Museum.

Palais Gyeongbogung
161 Sajik-ro
Jongno-gu,
Seoul

+82 (0)2 3700 3900

www.royalpalace.go.k
